metadata.title: 5-Minute Rundown of Model Development with Scikit-learn | by Mandy Gu | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5-Minute Rundown of Model Development with Scikit-learn
metadata.description: Recently, Edward Qian and I made a website that introduces Data Science fundamentals for beginners (check it out — www.dscrashcourse.com). This primer on scikit-learn can be found on the website…

all_paragraphs: Recently, Edward Qian and I made a website that introduces Data Science fundamentals for beginners (check it out — www.dscrashcourse.com). This primer on scikit-learn can be found on the website along with other Data Science resources and practice problems.
We want to showcase how easy it is to train a toy model using scikit-learn by using the famous Iris dataset as an example.

Commonly abbreviated as sklearn, scikit-learn is a Machine Learning library for Python. It supports model development across numerous algorithms in addition to tools for feature engineering, feature and model selection.
The purpose of this demonstration is to showcase scikit-learn features, regardless of practicality on such a small dataset. All code is in Python 3.
We will use the datasets module to load the Iris dataset. We can also use the pandas library and the numpy library to convert the data to a DataFrame for easier preprocessing.
The datasets module also provides a brief description about the dataset:

… The data set contains 3 classes of 50 instances each, where each class refers to a type of iris plant. One class is linearly separable from the other 2; the latter are NOT linearly separable from each other.
We can usedata.head()to preview the first 5 rows:
The target column represents the subspecies of iris.

We should always reserve part of our data for testing. Never test your model on the same data used to develop it. This is known as data leakage and it leads to overfitting which overestimates the model’s performance on subsequent observations.

The model selection module has several useful functions for splitting the dataset and for hyperparameter tuning. We will use sklearn.model_selection.train_test_split to randomly partition our dataset into a training set and a testing set.

How do we know which features we want to use in our model? How do we distinguish relevant predictors from noise? A lot of that comes down to domain knowledge, but this is also a process which can be automated by feature selection techniques. Scikit-learn has an entire module dedicated to that.

We will be using the SelectKbest function to select the top k prominent features. By setting k to be the same number of features we have available, we can use these outputs to quantify the relevancy of each feature. The F-test value for classification will be used as the scoring function.
The F value scores suggest that the petal dimensions are stronger predictors than the sepal dimensions.
These scores are hard to interpret on their own. We need to look at their corresponding p-values to determine the statistical significance of their effect on the target variables.
We can obtain the pvalues fromfeature_selection.pvalues_

P-value indicates the % of more “extreme” observations if the null hypothesis is true and if we repeat the same experiment many times. The null hypothesis here is that the feature has no effect on the target (i.e. we should not use it as a predictor).
Low p-values suggest we should reject our null hypothesis — in other words, reject the claim that the feature has no effect.
All we have to do is instantiate the classifier and call the fit method to train it over the training set.
Here is an example with Logistic Regression. The predict method for Logistic Regression returns the predicted class. The predict_proba method returns the probability scores for each class.
For more details on the Logistic Regression algorithm, click here.

After we train our model, we want to assess its performance. This can help us choose between candidate models and communicate model expectations to stakeholders. Scikit-learn’s metrics module can help us with this.
First, we use the model to predict labels for our testing set. Then we compare the predicted labels against the true labels to determine the performance.

The accuracy of our model is around 83%. The confusion matrix shows a breakdown of correct and incorrect classifications. The model is very good at identifying Setosa, but has trouble differentiating between the other two classes.
There you have it — a toy model trained in under 5 minutes using some of the core functionalities of scikit-learn.
Here is all of the code in one place:

I am also building a comprehensive set of free Data Science lessons. Check it out: www.dscrashcourse.com
